information is not a sign of weakness I tell by folks these days that saying I don't know is a superpower as long as

Beyond hey how much load can this specific technology handle um one of

able to actually do um effective work in your system um and then another point

the company in the long term like how have you dealt with that Blake yeah I like to think of the best

have a bungee cord attached to their belt that is attached at the other end to all those folks that they're leading
so there will be cases in whether it's hypergrowth in terms of teams or head count or it's it's hyper growth
and scalability and success you know maybe you're an overnight success in the marketplace and all of a sudden you

when you think about leading teams whether it's technical leadership or people leadership anytime you run
forward and progress you need to make sure that those teams that you're leading are pulling up behind you it
might not be at the same rate it might not even be at the same Pace every time it might vary depending on what you're going through but a big part of
leadership is lifting those up around you and I think I've seen some of the smartest people I've worked with in my
career fall down the most when they forget that fundamental truth of leadership is it's fundamentally not
about hero culture for me it's not about solving the most interesting technical
problems we have thought leaders in our industry you probably working with thought leaders in whatever industry

I would always describe as aggression in the sense of like really going for it
just grabbing work and a lot of organizations promote based on essentially people stepping outside of

talking about um and then I also think what I mentioned earlier sort of just developing some clarity where you where
you can and I think a big part of that is also about managing up and
essentially finding other ways to know that you're doing well like you probably won't have as Blake just said you
probably won't have a title change you probably won't have a clear document that lists your role and
responsibilities um and so there's a lot of having to make it up as you go and as the organization shifts around you um so
the one component that I've Just Seen incredibly helpful is managing up effectively so understanding what your
manager needs um understanding what your boss's boss needs um because that can

how to use those things to get wins for your boss um you know can you do this

yourself anymore um and also when working with your boss um one big big
step can also be to focus on outcomes and results instead of approaches because a lot of bosses in hypergrowth
and it's worth keeping mind they may struggle themselves this may also be a position they actually haven't ever been
in and so to like in a similar way as you're struggling with figuring out what to do they may do the same thing and so
if you can put some things forth as described earlier like say hey here's what I understand or here's what I've

current rool are you sort of elevating yourself up as the organization is growing around

that style is and leveraging it to great effect can be a really powerful tool but
also knowing what your weaknesses are and being honest about them you know I think decently inen and nice working
relationship I realized and we worked on this for months was that I have
basically two lovers and they're very specific to me but hopefully this resonates with somebody is is I can do
really well in situations where I have a lot going on so lots of tactical work
lots of things in flight and I can also do really well when there's a really high degree of
ambiguity so things are not clear we have rough shapes of gold we have
targets we might want to hit but not a clear idea of how to get there but when those two meters are Peak I do terrible
and it frustrates me and it burns me out and so figuring out what those levers are for you and how to dial them back I
think one of the most power powerful things that I realized working Lena with you was oh the things that I am doing
day to day that I am good at those are really good things to delegate and to
teach somebody else how to do because I know how to do them know what success looks like I know how to or at least I
learned on the job how to coach people through how to do things the way that I
do them and to know that output is different than the work going in to
produce that output so to say this is what I expect these are my expectations for whether it's a status report or
running a meeting or monthly planning or whatever the case may be but really
taking those things that I'm very comfortable with doing handing them off so that I can devote more time to the
things that make me a little more uncomfortable so flourishing in that ambiguity buying space for the things
that that I know I need to work on and just being open and honest you know I think a lot of times especially in hyper
growth it can feel like these opportunities are oh I just have to push this thing through I have to get it done
if I drop this thing on the ground it's going to be that's on me but but in all of these and I know that we both have a
a very team oriented perspective on these things is leaning on your team leaning on your peer managers your peer
technical uh leaders leaning on your boss leaning on your support system of
not spinning not doing things in the dark and hoping for an outcome but saying this is where I'm at doing that

show up as weakness it shows up as self-awareness which again is is massively valuable tool yeah I would I

really nicely in what you've alluded to earlier already about so your feeling of success and that's another thing that
